name: AI Ops CPG Roll-Up
one_liner: Acquire under-optimized CPG brands and boost profitability by installing a repeatable AI-powered operating system for inventory, marketing, CX, and reporting.

brief.problem:
Most small CPG brands don’t fail because the product is bad—they stall because operations are chaotic: inconsistent forecasting, stockouts, bloated spend, slow reporting, and manual workflows. This idea is to buy “good product / bad ops” brands (Amazon-native or DTC) and apply a standardized AI ops layer that quickly improves visibility, predictability, and scalability.

Core AI ops modules:
	•	Single source of truth: unify sales, ads, inventory, and finance into one dashboard with automated weekly reporting.
	•	Demand + inventory forecasting: reorder points, cash planning, and stockout prevention (improve fill rates, reduce dead inventory).
	•	Marketing ops automation: creative testing loops, budget pacing, attribution sanity checks, and margin-aware scaling.
	•	Customer support + voice of customer: automated triage, review mining, and product/positioning insights.
	•	Playbooks + integrations: templates, SOPs, and tooling that can be deployed in weeks—not months.

Who it’s for: operators/investors acquiring $1–10M revenue CPG brands that have real demand but are inefficient. The differentiation is compounding: every acquisition strengthens the shared platform (data, workflows, vendor playbooks), making future turnarounds faster and cheaper.

competition.reasoning: Traditional aggregators and PE shops exist (Thrasio, Branded, Heyday), but most focus on scale over operational tooling. Room for differentiation via AI ops, but capital-intensive model attracts competition.

team_fit.reasoning: Nick brings CPG operations, supply chain, and M&A expertise; Andrew has deep SMB/brand insight and paid media chops; Ben and Troy can build the AI ops infrastructure. Strong collective fit for identifying, acquiring, and optimizing brands.

bootstrappability.reasoning: Requires significant capital to acquire even one small brand ($100K–$500K+), plus inventory financing and working capital. Cannot bootstrap without external funding or personal capital deployment.

passive_potential.reasoning: Running physical product brands demands constant attention: inventory management, supplier issues, customer service, and marketing. Even with AI ops, brands require active oversight and decision-making.

side_project_viability.reasoning: Operating acquired CPG brands is a full-time commitment that cannot be managed at 4-8 hours/week. Inventory, cash flow, and supplier management require rapid response times incompatible with side-project constraints.

ai_leverage.reasoning: AI ops layer is core to the value creation thesis—forecasting, marketing automation, reporting, and CX can all meaningfully leverage LLMs and automation. Provides 10x improvement over manual spreadsheets and siloed tools.

revenue_clarity.reasoning: Revenue model is clear: acquire cash-flowing brands, improve EBITDA through operational efficiency, and either hold for cash flow or exit at higher multiple. Validated by aggregator exits and PE activity in the space.

market_timing.reasoning: CPG aggregator hype has cooled after Thrasio's struggles, creating potential buying opportunities at lower multiples. However, macro headwinds (inventory costs, consumer spending) and rising interest rates make financing harder.

summary: This is a PASS for a side project team, despite strong strategic merit. The fundamental issue is structural: acquiring and operating physical product brands requires significant upfront capital (impossible to bootstrap), full-time operational attention (inventory, suppliers, cash flow), and ongoing active management that cannot be squeezed into 4-8 hours per week across five people with day jobs. The team fit is excellent—Nick's CPG and M&A background, Andrew's brand/marketing expertise, and Ben/Troy's AI ops capabilities create a compelling operator profile—but this is a full-time venture or fund, not a side project. The AI ops thesis is sound and defensible (data moat strengthens with each acquisition), and the market timing is neutral with potential upside from depressed valuations, but execution demands are incompatible with your constraints. If the team is serious about this space, the path forward is either (1) building and selling the AI ops platform as standalone SaaS to existing CPG operators/aggregators, or (2) treating this as a future full-time venture once one or more team members can commit. As currently scoped, the idea scores 32/100—strategically interesting but operationally impossible given your side-project framework.
